pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:0.5: The second training rule on invitation
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.2: At that time two monks were traveling through the Kosalan country on their way to Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.4: and the second monk said to him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.6: Because of that the first monk became resentful.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.7: They then carried on to Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.8: Soon afterwards an association in Sāvatthī was offering a meal to the Sangha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.9: When the second monk had finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.10: the resentful monk went to his own family and got some almsfood. He then went to the other and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.14: And because he was pressured, he ate the almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.15: The resentful monk then said to him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.16: “Who are you to correct me when you eat food that’s not leftover even though you have finished your meal and refused an invitation to eat more?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.19: The second monk told the monks what had happened,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.20: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized the other monk,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.21: “How can a monk invite a monk who has finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more to eat food that’s not leftover?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.22: “Is it true, monk, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.25: “… Foolish man, how can you invite a monk who has finished eating and refused an invitation to eat more to eat food that’s not leftover?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.26: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.27: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:1.28.1: ‘If a monk invites a monk, whom he knows has finished his meal and refused an invitation to eat more, to eat staple or non-staple food that is not left over, saying, “Here, monk, eat,” aiming to criticize him, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.8: whom has eaten any of the five staple foods, even just what fits on the tip of a blade of grass.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.9: Refused an invitation to eat more:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.10: there is eating; there is staple food; it is offered by one standing within arm’s reach; there is a refusal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.12: the making it leftover is done with food that is not allowable;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.13: it is done with food that has not been received;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.14: it is done with food that is not held in hand;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.15: it is done by one who is not within arm’s reach;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.16: it is done by one who has not finished his meal;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.17: it is done by one who has finished his meal, who has refused an invitation to eat more, but who has risen from his seat;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.18: “I’ve had enough,” has not been said;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.19: it is not leftover from one who is sick—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.22: apart from the five staple foods, the post-midday tonics, the seven-day tonics, and the lifetime tonics—the rest is called “non-staple food”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.24: there are five kinds of staple food: cooked grain, porridge, flour, fish, and meat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.26: saying, “Take as much as you like.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.28: he knows by himself or others have told him or the monk has told him.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.30: if he offers it to him, thinking, “With this I’ll accuse him,” “I’ll remind him,” “I’ll counter-accuse him,” “I’ll counter-remind him,” “I’ll humiliate him,” he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.31: If, because of what he says, the other monk receives it with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.32: For every mouthful, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.1.33: When the other monk has finished eating, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.1: If the other monk has refused an invitation to eat more, and he perceives that he has, and he invites him to eat staple or non-staple food which is not leftover, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.2: If the other monk has refused an invitation to eat more, but he is unsure of it, and he invites him to eat staple or non-staple food which is not leftover, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.3: If the other monk has refused an invitation to eat more, but he does not perceive that he has, and he invites him to eat staple or non-staple food which is not leftover, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.4: If he invites him to eat post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics for the purpose of food, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.5: If, because of what he says, the other monk receives it with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.6: For every mouthful, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.7: If the other monk has not refused an invitation to eat more, but he perceives that he has, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.8: If the other monk has not refused an invitation to eat more, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.2.9: If the other monk has not refused an invitation to eat more, and he does not perceive that he has, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.2: if he gives it after having it made leftover;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.3: if he gives it, saying, “Have it made leftover and then eat it;”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.4: if he gives it, saying, “Take this food for the benefit of someone else;”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.5: if he gives the leftovers from a sick person;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.6: if he gives, saying, “When there’s a reason, make use of these post-midday tonics,” “… make use of these seven-day tonics,” “… make use of these lifetime tonics;”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.8: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc36:2.3.9: The sixth rule, the second training rule on invitation, is finished.
